Intuitively, it seems wrong to deny that the person knows the proposition simply because of external bad luck.}, {The idea that knowledge is contingent on luck outcomes concerning practical benefits is implausible as it undermines the internalist nature of knowledge.}

e997f938-9a78-44a8-a93a-e16be751300c.summary: Does pragmatic benefit equal knowledge in all contexts?
e997f938-9a78-44a8-a93a-e16be751300c.content: {Consider a case in which a person benefits only tangentially from a true belief, such as a random unrelated success that was not the target of the belief. Intuitively, this incidental success should not qualify as a demonstration of knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge is primarily about cognitive, not pragmatic, accuracy, which such distracted benefits do not confirm.}

f6773b79-7b46-479f-b058-f80f91c81918.summary: How do we account for knowledge without practical benefit in abstract domains?
f6773b79-7b46-479f-b058-f80f91c81918.content: {Consider scenarios such as mathematical or philosophical truths where there may be knowledge despite little to no immediate practical benefit. Intuitively, these are cases of knowledge even with no direct pragmatic outcomes.}, {It is implausible that such abstract knowledge should be dismissed merely due to the absence of practical utility.}

3836e440-3a99-4288-8678-83c1a0a47a72.summary: Is truth enough to determine the success of actions derived from beliefs?
3836e440-3a99-4288-8678-83c1a0a47a72.content: {Suppose a person operates under a true belief but fails in their action not because the belief was false, but due to unrelated situational factors. Intuitively, their knowledge should not be dismissed just because the pragmatic component fails due to external factors.}, {There is a plausible principle that the truth condition should not be threatened by external pragmatic failures that don't relate directly to the belief in question.}

413152ec-3485-4a20-8cac-de90e6a9cd65.summary: Could someone achieve pragmatic success with false beliefs?
413152ec-3485-4a20-8cac-de90e6a9cd65.content: {Suppose a person believes a false proposition but acts in such a way that results in successful outcomes due to sheer luck or coincidence. Intuitively, it is clear that pragmatic success alone does not suffice for knowledge if truth is absent.}, {There is a plausible principle that even false beliefs can lead to practical success, which demonstrates that action success is separate from the truth condition required for knowledge.}

18c0154e-625f-4753-8776-7f7594e08803.summary: Are all beliefs that lead to practical benefits truly knowledge?
18c0154e-625f-4753-8776-7f7594e08803.content: {Consider someone holding a superstition that turns out to lead to correct actions purely coincidentally, resulting in practical benefit. Intuitively, these should not be considered cases of true knowledge as the belief itself is not based in reality.}, {It is implausible that practical success resulting from false, superstitious beliefs aligns with genuine knowledge.}

9e9d7aaf-074d-4de2-89cd-1306de0f6b6e.summary: Does coincidence in action success undermine the principle of pragmatic knowledge?
9e9d7aaf-074d-4de2-89cd-1306de0f6b6e.content: {Imagine a scenario where a person acts successfully under a correct belief, but only due to unrelated coincidences rather than the truth of the belief informing the action. Intuitively, we would not attribute genuine knowledge to such cases.}, {The accidental success in application of belief does not correlate with a plausible principle of what knowledge truly encompasses.}

d2394a38-75ff-4364-a8e3-6eb0bde57c68.summary: Is it possible for individuals to have theoretical knowledge without practical consequences?
d2394a38-75ff-4364-a8e3-6eb0bde57c68.content: {Consider a scholar who comprehends deep theoretical truths about the universe which cannot be practically implemented. Intuitively, the scholar is considered knowledgeable even in the absence of practical application.}, {There is a plausible principle that recognizes theoretical knowledge as valuable independently from its practical utility.}

952c1477-9c8b-4664-a22a-fcbfb45ce410.summary: Do errors in action negate existing knowledge of a truth?
952c1477-9c8b-4664-a22a-fcbfb45ce410.content: {Suppose a person knows a true proposition and acts on it, but makes an unrelated mistake that prevents the practical benefit. Intuitively, failing to get practical benefit should not negate their knowledge of the proposition.}, {It is implausible to deny knowledge based solely on practical error unrelated to the truth of the belief itself.}

dc8d85b4-6374-4e6d-8103-fbeaf901aa28.summary: Can subjective success in action correlate with objective truth of beliefs?
dc8d85b4-6374-4e6d-8103-fbeaf901aa28.content: {Consider a person whose subjective strategy happens to yield successful action, even if the basis for their original belief was flawed. Intuitively, subjective success does not equate to genuine knowledge without an objective grounding.}, {There is a plausible principle that subjective action success should not redefine the objective necessity of truth in knowledge.}

efad55f2-b691-48f3-8dfe-12ed6042698a.summary: Must knowledge be tied to opportunistic benefits?
efad55f2-b691-48f3-8dfe-12ed6042698a.content: {Imagine someone who believes a true proposition but deliberately chooses not to act on it for personal reasons. Intuitively, this inaction does not eliminate the person’s knowledge of the truth.}, {It is implausible to tie the existence of knowledge to opportunistic or circumstantial action when personal or ethical choices dictate otherwise.}

f9dfc465-95cc-4694-989e-519702de563c.summary: Should trivial truths that lead to successful actions be termed as knowledge?
f9dfc465-95cc-4694-989e-519702de563c.content: {Consider a person who successfully acts on a trivial true belief, like the number of tiles on a neighbor's roof, which aids him in winning a random bet. Intuitively, such trivial truths, despite yielding practical benefits, should not necessarily be regarded as deep or meaningful knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that not all pragmatic successes derived from trivial truths should equate to acknowledged knowledge, given the context and impact of the belief.}

eaf3b778-7199-497c-b17d-1097d41324fd.summary: Can knowledge be defined solely by pragmatic utility?
eaf3b778-7199-497c-b17d-1097d41324fd.content: {Suppose an individual holds a belief that aligns neatly with societal norms, resulting in personal success, yet the belief in itself offers little in terms of cognitive insight. Intuitively, such knowledge defined by mere conformity and utility seems lacking.}, {It is implausible to equate knowledge strictly with the level of pragmatic utility, overlooking the broader intellectual merits of the belief itself.}

d17ab4ff-925a-46af-9bb4-12880b5a4859.summary: Can a proposition known by perception pose a problem for the necessity of intellectual intuition?
d17ab4ff-925a-46af-9bb4-12880b5a4859.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person sees a tree and believes that a tree is there. Intuitively, this person's belief is justified through perception rather than intellectual intuition.}, {It seems plausible that perception can justify beliefs without the need for intellectual intuition.}, {If a belief justified through direct perception counts as knowledge, then intellectual intuition may not be necessary for knowledge.}

db1e3d9c-d568-4cfe-a397-02d3fb8bce0b.summary: Does false belief generated by intellectual intuition still challenge the sufficiency of these conditions?
db1e3d9c-d568-4cfe-a397-02d3fb8bce0b.content: {Suppose a person has a belief generated by intellectual intuition that a particular false claim is true. Intuitively, this cannot be knowledge because knowledge requires truth.}, {If the belief is generated by intellectual intuition but the proposition is false, the conditions for knowledge are not met, undermining sufficiency.}, {A situation where intellectual intuition leads to a false belief suggests that intellectual intuition alone is not sufficient for knowledge.}

e13ed29d-e98d-4d4f-9afe-81607cd6caaa.summary: Can memory-based knowledge contest the necessity of intellectual intuition?
e13ed29d-e98d-4d4f-9afe-81607cd6caaa.content: {Consider a scenario where a person remembers an event from the past and believes a proposition about the event. Intuitively, this memory-based belief doesn't involve intellectual intuition.}, {Memory can provide justification and lead to knowledge without involving any form of intellectual intuition.}, {If memory can justify true beliefs without intellectual intuition, then the necessity of intellectual intuition for knowledge is challenged.}

2a859739-63c9-43a7-86ff-bc8135eaf121.summary: Does the requirement that belief is generated by intellectual intuition exclude scientific knowledge?
2a859739-63c9-43a7-86ff-bc8135eaf121.content: {Scientific knowledge often involves empirical methods and deduction rather than direct intellectual intuition.}, {Consider a scientist using experiments and calculations to arrive at a scientific conclusion. Intuitively, this process does not involve intellectual intuition.}, {If scientific knowledge, which is considered a paradigm of knowledge, does not always involve intellectual intuition, this challenges the necessity of such intuition for all knowledge.}

ab70f955-2213-4467-ac1e-1390a5e18877.summary: Does the theory adequately handle the Gettier problem?
ab70f955-2213-4467-ac1e-1390a5e18877.content: {Consider a case where a person believes a true proposition because of intellectual intuition, but there is an element of luck or deception involved. Intuitively, this belief does not seem to constitute knowledge.}, {The presence of luck or error in forming a belief can prevent a belief generated by intellectual intuition from being considered knowledge, as demonstrated by Gettier-type cases.}, {If a correct belief arises in part due to an accidental truth factor, then merely having intellectual intuition does not guarantee knowledge, as illustrated by these cases.}

ced3e457-ebb7-4f64-b576-f6477ddea433.summary: Can a proposition known without belief challenge the necessity condition on believing the proposition?
ced3e457-ebb7-4f64-b576-f6477ddea433.content: {Consider a case in which someone apprehends a mathematical truth but claims not to actively believe it because they have direct insight. Intuitively, apprehending this truth could count as knowledge.}, {There might be scenarios where understanding or grasping a truth does not involve what is normally called belief, but still seems like knowledge.}, {If apprehension without active belief is possible, the claim that belief is necessary for knowledge is questionable.}

a2c1bee4-5916-4482-ba42-80d449c0d8b5.summary: Does disagreement among intuitionists challenge the reliability of intellectual intuition?
a2c1bee4-5916-4482-ba42-80d449c0d8b5.content: {There is a plausible observation that intellectual intuitions can lead different philosophers to differing conclusions, for example, on ethical matters.}, {Such disagreements among those relying on intellectual intuition suggest that this method is not always reliable.}, {If intellectual intuition can yield contradictory beliefs, then its role as a condition for knowledge is problematic.}

e5001d9e-de24-4f6b-96fb-89d802410aaa.summary: Is the notion of intellectual intuition too vague to function as a reliable criterion for knowledge?
e5001d9e-de24-4f6b-96fb-89d802410aaa.content: {The concept of intellectual intuition lacks a precise definition and can be interpreted in varying ways.}, {Without a clear understanding of what constitutes intellectual intuition, it is difficult to apply it consistently as a criterion for knowledge.}, {The vagueness of intellectual intuition makes it hard to use reliably to differentiate between mere belief and knowledge.}

79958ada-ec35-497b-9860-44a9982132b3.summary: Could an appeal to intellectual intuition be circular or question-begging?
79958ada-ec35-497b-9860-44a9982132b3.content: {Consider the scenario where someone claims to know through intellectual intuition that intellectual intuition is a valid criterion for knowledge. Intuitively, this seems question-begging.}, {If one justifies the validity of intellectual intuition through intellectual intuition itself, this reasoning becomes circular.}, {Using intellectual intuition to validate itself raises the problem of circularity, which undermines its reliability as a foundation for knowledge.}

a6695dc4-524c-47f7-9a81-ab1042e40a36.content: {There are situations where a person believes a proposition, the proposition is true, and the justification is seemingly complete, yet unrecognized defeaters could subtly undermine the justification.}, {Consider a case where a scientist firmly believes a theory because all observable evidence supports it, yet unidentified anomalies (unknown defeaters) hidden in unexamined data could potentially invalidate the justification for the theory.}

4120c6ce-a4ad-4dba-96f4-4e34b9bd25b7.summary: Can justification be fully independent of community knowledge?
4120c6ce-a4ad-4dba-96f4-4e34b9bd25b7.content: {There are cases where what counts as justification for a belief is determined by the collective knowledge of a community, and undefeated defeaters might exist according to that community's standards even if unknown to the individual.}, {Consider a scenario in which an archaeologist believes a proposition about an artifact's origin based on preliminary findings; however, broader scholarly consensus recognizes counter-evidence that the archaeologist is unaware of, serving as a defeater.}

00dfb275-ca66-402f-b487-93991eb11123.content: {Many times, defeaters are implicit in cultural or background assumptions, meaning individuals might hold a belief, the proposition is true, and they appear justified without recognizing these implicit defeaters.}, {In a scenario where a historian concludes a historical event's occurrence based on available documentation, implicit cultural biases in the documentation, unknown to the historian, could act as hidden defeaters.}

c4775156-ff64-4ef8-8707-67303b2670d3.content: {In some complex domains such as quantum physics or frontier scientific research, available evidence might be incomplete, making it practically impossible to identify all potential defeaters, challenging the sufficiency of known principles.}, {Consider a physicist who forms a belief based on current quantum mechanics models; unknown variables (potential defeaters) might affect justification but remain elusive due to current technological or theoretical limitations.}

7ad8ea54-86d7-4b4b-bba2-b67e28cb33f7.summary: Do emotions play a role in ignoring defeaters?
7ad8ea54-86d7-4b4b-bba2-b67e28cb33f7.content: {Individuals might hold beliefs, which are true and justified, but their emotional attachment to these beliefs could lead them to ignore or underestimate the significance of defeaters.}, {Imagine a politician who believes in a policy's efficacy based on various reports and data; personal biases and emotional investment might blind them to significant confounding evidence that acts as a defeater.}

bf062762-a0d9-440e-83f2-a92e8403d01e.content: {In group settings, social pressures and groupthink can cause individuals to overlook or dismiss defeaters, resulting in a justified belief of a true proposition that appears knowledge from within the group but might not withstand external scrutiny.}, {Consider a corporate board where all members believe a business strategy is sound due to shared optimism and reinforcement, yet the existence of external market trends unknown to the group might serve as defeaters.}

93013385-2ff2-4e49-81f3-afaa77c80097.summary: Can rapidly changing contexts render justification unstable?
93013385-2ff2-4e49-81f3-afaa77c80097.content: {In environments where information updates rapidly, what counts as an undefeated defeater may shift quickly, undermining the stability of justification for beliefs that seem true when assessed with current but soon outdated data.}, {A technology trader might justify their belief in market predictions with present statistics, only for sudden technological shifts to introduce unanticipated variables that serve as defeaters to that justification.}

e27f322c-606f-4cb0-a931-8d947868f362.content: {Some defeaters might be epistemically significant while others are trivial, suggesting that not all undefeated defeaters equally affect whether a belief constitutes knowledge.}, {In legal reasoning, a lawyer may justify a client's defense with robust arguments, while minor, previously overlooked legal statutes could technically act as defeaters without diminishing the strength of the overall justification significantly.}

63c1e2fa-75b4-4dc9-9016-d17fbaf33100.summary: Does the notion of sufficient justification presuppose perfect epistemic access?
63c1e2fa-75b4-4dc9-9016-d17fbaf33100.content: {The idea that justification is sufficient for knowledge presupposes that individuals have perfect epistemic access to all possible defeaters, which is implausible given the limitation of human cognition and information.}, {Consider an environmental scientist who believes a hypothesis on climate change based on extensive data sets, yet access to or understanding of potential methodological errors might limit recognition of defeaters.}

8a9a265f-d717-4109-9c90-1486446d1905.summary: Can an infinite regress of reasons provide genuine justification?
8a9a265f-d717-4109-9c90-1486446d1905.content: {Infinite regresses are generally considered problematic because they lack a definitive grounding point.}, {If justification requires an infinite series of reasons, it is impossible for a person to possess complete justification because no human can actually traverse an infinite series.}

8c6168f6-ecd1-42f2-9e6d-9184c113d78e.summary: Are human cognitive limits compatible with infinitism?
8c6168f6-ecd1-42f2-9e6d-9184c113d78e.content: {Human cognitive capacities are inherently limited in terms of time and resources.}, {For a person to understand or access an infinite series of reasons, they would surpass human cognitive limits which is not feasible.}

b822a55a-b913-44de-bc15-4325e52400a3.summary: Does infinitism lead to skepticism about knowledge?
b822a55a-b913-44de-bc15-4325e52400a3.content: {Infinitism requires an endless chain of reasons for justification.}, {If justification always requires an endless chain, then it implies that no belief is ever fully justified, leading to skepticism about all knowledge claims.}

1c55dc99-5c53-4c2a-a085-b6cb43abc701.summary: Can infinitism address the problem of arbitrariness?
1c55dc99-5c53-4c2a-a085-b6cb43abc701.content: {If justification requires an infinite chain and cannot terminate, then no particular reason in the chain seems fundamentally more crucial than another.}, {Without a terminating or foundational reason, any chosen justification might appear arbitrary because there is no specific grounding point.}

aa021a76-fd56-4f82-b225-346bb8baebd3.summary: How does infinitism account for practical reason-giving?
aa021a76-fd56-4f82-b225-346bb8baebd3.content: {In practical scenarios, reasons for beliefs or actions need to be communicated briefly and effectively.}, {An infinite series of reasons would be impractical for decision-making and impossible to communicate in real-world situations.}

ecc4f89c-662e-42f4-b9b5-de014547bab3.summary: Does infinitism allow for certainty in knowledge?
ecc4f89c-662e-42f4-b9b5-de014547bab3.content: {Certainty about knowledge requires a firm grounding that offers conclusive reasons.}, {An endless chain of reasons provides no firm anchoring, so it fails to offer the certainty required for knowledge.}

7a55d8e4-d7a3-4990-b96a-723b0494690c.summary: Is infinitism susceptible to vicious regress?
7a55d8e4-d7a3-4990-b96a-723b0494690c.content: {A regress becomes vicious if it is intended to solve a problem but instead perpetuates it without solution.}, {Since infinitism never reaches a foundational justification, it perpetuates the need for further justification perpetually, without satisfying the original requirement for knowledge.}

fffc4e8b-0126-4888-812f-235beffb7e8a.summary: How does infinitism reconcile with the finitude of human reasoning?
fffc4e8b-0126-4888-812f-235beffb7e8a.content: {Human reasoning processes and capacities are finite.}, {If knowledge requires an infinite reason chain, this clashes with the necessity for humans to function within finite cognitive and temporal bounds.}

894027d9-78e4-4ee3-a36a-22c0b2c484c9.summary: Can beliefs be reliably justified through infinitism?
894027d9-78e4-4ee3-a36a-22c0b2c484c9.content: {For belief justification to be reliable, one should be able to verify the reasons given.}, {An infinite regress implies that the chain can never be completely verified, thus undermining the reliability of belief justification.}

ccd7a2a5-3c51-4421-95b4-bee6345f912d.summary: Is infinite justification accessible or demonstrable in practice?
ccd7a2a5-3c51-4421-95b4-bee6345f912d.content: {For a belief to be practically justified, the justification process should be accessible or demonstrable to some degree.}, {An infinite chain of reasons is neither accessible nor practically demonstrable, thereby failing the practical demands of justification.}

8447474c-ed50-4b28-a5e4-5dba2badc949.content: {An endless justification chain might circle back at some point without reaching a novel or independent justification.}, {If the reasoning becomes circular to compensate for the infinite chain, it undermines its own justification by relying on previously stated reasons.}

d8312b23-0223-48e0-b469-a50516cea020.summary: Is the notion of infinity meaningful in epistemic contexts?
d8312b23-0223-48e0-b469-a50516cea020.content: {Infinity is a concept that is challenging to apply meaningfully outside of abstract mathematics or theoretical constructs.}, {Applying an infinite series of reasons to epistemic justification might lack practical meaning and applicability, as epistemic contexts require finite ascertainable evidence.}

0a78cd63-7367-4bb2-95cc-237104fa2dc0.summary: Does infinitism undermine the practical purpose of justification?
0a78cd63-7367-4bb2-95cc-237104fa2dc0.content: {The primary function of justification is to solidify belief as knowledge in a practical stance.}, {An infinitely regressive justification system may not fulfill this role effectively as it lacks a definitive end to secure practical belief formation.}

3fa20d65-6c84-41dc-9cc5-6f055180d89b.summary: Is the demand for infinite reasons epistemically excessive?
3fa20d65-6c84-41dc-9cc5-6f055180d89b.content: {Epistemic demands are generally seen as requiring adequate but not excessive justification.}, {An infinite requirement might be seen as excessive, adding an undue epistemic burden beyond what is normally considered necessary for valid justification.}

16547c43-b081-4b59-b0be-db26349f2c5d.summary: Can infinitism assure a progression towards truth?
16547c43-b081-4b59-b0be-db26349f2c5d.content: {Justification is meant to lead progressively towards truth through each successive reason.}, {With no endpoint in sight, an infinite chain may never actually arrive at the truth, but remain indefinitely inquiring without conclusion.}

68a0dc13-0cf6-44ce-ab61-9ad11323096e.summary: Are infinite regress arguments self-defeating for justification?
68a0dc13-0cf6-44ce-ab61-9ad11323096e.content: {It's argued that logically valid justifications require completing processes to eventually reach a point of acceptance.}, {By never completing, an infinite regress could defeat its purpose by negating the potential for definitive acceptance, thus defeating justification attempts.}

c6a658b4-42a1-4dc2-83ca-ad8be162bf67.summary: Is the requirement of infinite reasons plausible for mundane beliefs?
c6a658b4-42a1-4dc2-83ca-ad8be162bf67.content: {Everyday beliefs, like believing it's raining outside, seem to not need infinite justification but are usually accepted with finite evidence.}, {Demanding an infinite justification for simple beliefs seems implausible and unnecessary given the adequacy of finite reasoning in quotidian contexts.}

62f888e3-faa6-4a04-b2db-6584dcd12043.summary: Can a justified true belief be false knowledge?
62f888e3-faa6-4a04-b2db-6584dcd12043.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person sees a clock showing 3 PM, believes it is 3 PM, and it is actually 3 PM. However, the clock stopped at 3 PM yesterday. Intuitively, we would judge that the person does not know it is 3 PM despite having a justified true belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that if someone knows a proposition, their knowledge cannot be based on coincidental circumstances. This principle suggests that having justification, truth, and belief is not sufficient for knowledge in all cases.}

37e60cce-a0bb-4c80-8b93-3c0a7030600b.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person forms the belief that a particular horse will win a race because they randomly hear someone shouting it, and this horse wins the race. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person knows the horse would win or that they did not. If we say they know, then we accept knowledge through luck, which seems implausible.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should not be dependent on coincidence or luck. This principle suggests that mere justified true belief can involve too much luck to constitute knowledge.}

09133060-3e21-4fed-9c76-1040becbdc0a.summary: Does justification always prevent false knowledge?
09133060-3e21-4fed-9c76-1040becbdc0a.content: {A person could have a justified belief that it will rain based on a weather forecast, and it does rain, though the forecast was generated through a glitch generating wrong predictions during a period it almost always rains, making the belief true coincidentally. Intuitively, we might judge that the belief was not knowledge despite being justified and true.}, {It is plausible that knowledge requires reliability in the method of justification. This suggests that justified true belief does not always guarantee knowledge when the true belief results from an unreliable method.}

4b4d3bbf-fa50-4d75-90a4-0aaba610cf97.summary: Can someone know through false premises?
4b4d3bbf-fa50-4d75-90a4-0aaba610cf97.content: {Consider a case where a person has a justified true belief that their friend is at their regular coffee shop because they see their friend’s distinctive car parked outside. Unbeknownst to them, the car is coincidentally identical to their friend’s car, and the belief turns out true because their friend walked to the shop. Intuitively, the person does not know their friend is at the shop despite their justified true belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowing requires correct reasoning from true premises. This suggests that justified true belief is not sufficient for knowledge if the premises leading to the conclusion are false.}

2f188d3c-2f6f-43ff-96c1-78dde12fee33.summary: Could true belief be accidentally justified?
2f188d3c-2f6f-43ff-96c1-78dde12fee33.content: {Imagine a person who believes a historical fact because they misremember watching a documentary. The fact happens to be true. Intuitively, we judge that this person lacks knowledge despite having a true belief and feeling justified due to their error in memory.}, {There is a plausible principle that true beliefs must be based on good evidence to qualify as knowledge. This principle suggests accidental justification does not suffice for knowledge even if the belief is true.}

6b2493bf-d3fe-4557-a9f9-982014596503.content: {A scientist regularly sees a substance react consistently under certain conditions, forming a justified belief about a natural law. On one occasion, a random external factor causes a different reaction, unbeknownst to the scientist. The belief about the natural law remains true despite misleading evidence, yet intuitively, the scientist does not know due to the atypical disconfirmation.}, {It is plausible that misleading evidence undermines knowledge. This suggests that even with justified true belief, knowledge can be disrupted by misleading evidence.}

c92ec222-abd1-4e7f-a26d-10f1b8fc907b.summary: Can knowledge exist without causal connection?
c92ec222-abd1-4e7f-a26d-10f1b8fc907b.content: {Suppose a person believes a distant volcano erupted at the exact same time they are thinking about it without any causal information source. Surprisingly, the volcano does erupt. Intuitively, without any causal connection or information flow, we might say the person does not know of the eruption.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowing requires some causal or informative connection to the truth of the proposition. This suggests that justified true belief without such connection is not sufficient for knowledge.}

b0e94617-9bc0-4e7b-b431-1315c43d73af.summary: How does epistemic luck challenge knowledge?
b0e94617-9bc0-4e7b-b431-1315c43d73af.content: {Consider a student who guesses the answer to a multiple-choice question correctly without any knowledge or skill. Although they have a true belief, it is based on pure luck. Intuitively, we would not say the student knows the answer, although the proposition believed is true.}, {It is plausible that epistemic luck undermines knowledge. This suggests that justified true belief is insufficient for knowledge if it is achieved through epistemic luck.}

51b6c5a1-464b-40fe-88af-d8ab8e34143b.content: {In a low-stakes context, a person has a justified true belief about the whereabouts of a location based on a friend’s direction. In a high-stakes situation, the same justification feels insufficient. Intuitively, we might deem the belief insufficient for knowledge in the high-stakes case despite being justified and true.}, {There is a plausible principle that the sufficiency of justification for knowledge can depend on contextual factors. This suggests that justified true belief may be insufficient for knowledge if context changes its sufficiency.}

9a6d1c59-4b49-4072-b57c-076f5c00698d.content: {A detective correctly identifies a culprit based on misleading evidence influenced by corrupt authorities. Despite their belief being true, it feels accidental given the unreliable evidence. Intuitively, this accidental truth suggests the detective does not have knowledge.}, {It is plausible that knowledge requires non-accidental truth. This suggests that justified true belief that is true accidentally does not count as knowledge.}

806a1a74-64a5-40be-aee7-77022d6544dd.summary: Can a reliable process lead to false beliefs that do not constitute knowledge?
806a1a74-64a5-40be-aee7-77022d6544dd.content: {Consider a scenario where a person uses a highly reliable but slightly faulty thermometer to measure the temperature, and it reads 70°F. Intuitively, we would judge that if the thermometer occasionally fails and reads incorrectly, the person does not know the temperature is 70°F even if this instance happens to be correct.}, {A reliable process must consistently produce true beliefs; slight unreliability challenges the sufficiency of reliability for knowledge.}

58816bf8-4e04-4750-b188-ed23815b2e77.summary: Does the presence of epistemic luck undermine knowledge in reliabilism?
58816bf8-4e04-4750-b188-ed23815b2e77.content: {Imagine a case where a person believes it will rain because they accidentally see an outdated weather forecast predicting rain, yet it rains due to unrelated meteorological events. Intuitively, we would judge that this person's belief is true due to luck, not knowledge.}, {Epistemic luck occurs when a true belief results from accidental factors unrelated to reliable processes, indicating that true belief alone is not sufficient for knowledge.}

b4664e36-a9a8-4bde-b277-7bac61cba090.summary: Can we define reliability without circularity when applied to knowledge?
b4664e36-a9a8-4bde-b277-7bac61cba090.content: {Assume that someone claims a cognitive process is reliable if it produces mostly true beliefs. The challenge is in defining what constitutes "mostly true" without already assuming some concept of knowledge.}, {The definition of reliability requires a measure that does not presuppose the concept of knowledge to avoid circular reasoning.}

b12067e7-2016-47c4-bb30-8fdaa8dc2678.summary: Do highly reliable processes always guarantee the absence of misleading evidence?
b12067e7-2016-47c4-bb30-8fdaa8dc2678.content: {Suppose a cognitive process generally leads to true beliefs except in rare cases where misleading evidence is present, such as a trusted but deceptive informant. Intuitively, we would judge that beliefs formed under deception do not amount to knowledge.}, {Misleading evidence can cause reliable processes to yield false beliefs, showing that reliability alone does not ensure knowledge.}

240fc784-1826-4589-8b90-9c31e413635d.summary: Is it possible for two people to have the same cognitive process with different reliability outcomes?
240fc784-1826-4589-8b90-9c31e413635d.content: {Imagine two identical twins using the same method for reasoning, but one happens to live in a world where their process yields false beliefs due to environmental differences. Intuitively, we would judge that only the twin in the environmentally favorable world knows.}, {Identical cognitive processes across different contexts can yield divergent reliability, questioning the context-independence of reliability as a measure for knowledge.}

49236c24-4bac-4479-a3f5-b0067cff6791.summary: Does reliabilism account for the internal justification of beliefs?
49236c24-4bac-4479-a3f5-b0067cff6791.content: {Consider a person who believes a proposition because of a reliable process but cannot provide any reasons or justification for why they believe it. Intuitively, we might question if this belief truly counts as knowledge.}, {Reliability solely emphasizes external factors, potentially excluding the necessity of internal justification, challenging its sufficiency for knowledge.}

4ca4267a-0264-4bd0-957d-43bb76fc5ed7.summary: Can the reliability of a belief-forming process be known or accessible to the believer?
4ca4267a-0264-4bd0-957d-43bb76fc5ed7.content: {Suppose a person has a true belief formed by a reliable but unknown process, such as a genetically enhanced ability unknown to them. Intuitively, it is questionable whether they truly know the proposition.}, {The knower's awareness of the reliability of their cognitive processes is often inaccessible, raising issues about the transparency of reliability in knowledge.}

988b24c8-d8d0-4288-9263-c14ef4fa871d.summary: Does reliabilism appropriately account for changes in reliability over time?
988b24c8-d8d0-4288-9263-c14ef4fa871d.content: {Imagine a situation where a belief was formed by a reliable process that becomes unreliable later due to new developments, such as technology malfunctioning. Intuitively, we wonder if the past reliability still justifies current knowledge claims.}, {Changing reliability of cognitive processes introduces doubts about the stability and ongoing justification of beliefs formed through them.}

2204ca20-a558-4cef-85ba-0a9e451bc564.summary: Is there a distinction between reliable and unreliable processes when forming contingent beliefs?
2204ca20-a558-4cef-85ba-0a9e451bc564.content: {Suppose two individuals reach the same true belief about an event via different processes, one generally reliable, another erratically reliable due to rare insights. Intuitively, both share a true belief, but one is unreliable, suggesting differences matter for knowledge.}, {Distinguishing between process reliability when contingent factors are involved questions if identical outcomes suggest equal knowledge status.}

07985056-7473-4a8b-81cb-cb90ea9a1eaf.summary: How do reliabilism and Gettier problems relate?
07985056-7473-4a8b-81cb-cb90ea9a1eaf.content: {Imagine a situation where a person believes a true proposition due to a logical deduction from a false premise that is coincidentally true. Intuitively, such a scenario exemplifies a Gettier problem, questioning knowledge claims despite reliability links.}, {Gettier cases demonstrate situations where reliable processes are undermined by additional, complex variables like false premises, challenging the guarantee of knowledge.}

6cae55d8-eb8a-496a-9aeb-0a81be924c36.summary: Can people have knowledge without realizing it through a false lemma?
6cae55d8-eb8a-496a-9aeb-0a81be924c36.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person believes a proposition based on a justified true belief and this belief was not derived through any false lemma. Intuitively, we would judge that this person has knowledge.}, {Consider a scenario where another person has a true belief formed in the same manner but without awareness of the potential role of an unnoticed false lemma. Intuitively, it seems this person might also know the proposition.}

ee805c52-1df6-44b6-9b08-c373ea05f5d1.summary: Does the theory collapse in cases of environmental luck?
ee805c52-1df6-44b6-9b08-c373ea05f5d1.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person forms a belief based on good justification and the belief turns out to be true but the environment is unreliable, leading to frequent false beliefs for similar reasons. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person knows the proposition or that they do not. If we say they know it, then knowledge seems overly generous. If we say they do not know it, then justified true beliefs can lack knowledge without the interference of a false lemma.}

47668080-8033-4161-8686-182cf8c86e05.summary: Is the use of the term "justification" adequate in accounting for reliable beliefs?
47668080-8033-4161-8686-182cf8c86e05.content: {There is a plausible principle that justification should track reliability. This principle together with the No False Lemmas Theory entails that any justified belief conforming to this theory should also reflect the usual reliability of similar beliefs in similar situations. This seems implausible when an individual has justification that does not align with broadly reliable outcomes.}

1ffa30fe-c7f8-485c-8751-b4ab7cfb2b6c.summary: Do Gettier cases undermine the sufficiency clause?
1ffa30fe-c7f8-485c-8751-b4ab7cfb2b6c.content: {Consider a scenario where an individual, Alex, sees a clock that reads 10 a.m. and believes it is 10 a.m., which it is. However, the clock stopped working exactly 12 hours ago and only coincidentally reads the correct time now. Intuitively, we would judge that Alex does not have knowledge, even though his belief seems justified and true and has no false lemmas.}

2702fa5c-2c8b-419e-9037-bd02ef089a15.summary: Can justified beliefs formed by unreliable processes be considered knowledge?
2702fa5c-2c8b-419e-9037-bd02ef089a15.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person forms a true and justified belief through an unreliable cognitive process, such as flipping a coin to make a decision. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person knows the proposition or that they do not. If we say they know it, then the concept of knowledge disregards the unreliability of its formation. If we say they do not know it, then our emphasis on justification without false propositions may be misplaced.}

1441ecf2-81c1-4fc7-98bd-a7d1b24eadbb.summary: Does the theory accommodate the role of cognitive achievements?
1441ecf2-81c1-4fc7-98bd-a7d1b24eadbb.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should involve some level of cognitive achievement, where an individual arrives at a true belief through reliable cognitive effort. This principle together with the No False Lemmas Theory entails that mere possession of a true justified belief without a false lemma satisfies cognitive achievement. However, this seems counterintuitive when the belief results from mere luck or accident.}

b0237b1b-909a-4137-8d34-462c902ce612.summary: Do cases with misleading evidence challenge the theory?
b0237b1b-909a-4137-8d34-462c902ce612.content: {Consider a scenario where a person has a justified but false belief based on substantial misleading evidence, but their belief turns out to be true by coincidence. Intuitively, we might judge that their belief is not knowledge, even though no false lemma is involved in the justification for the truth of the belief.}

1f8ba5d9-02c0-428f-98b5-90208b4e2ee6.summary: Can the absence of false lemmas guarantee the security of justification?
1f8ba5d9-02c0-428f-98b5-90208b4e2ee6.content: {It is implausible that the mere absence of a false lemma ensures the security of justification, as a belief system could be free of false lemmas and yet be based on inherently unreliable or arbitrary processes. This challenges the assumption that no false lemma brings about a secure justification.}

8813e364-2106-4815-91bf-c756cc40c9d8.summary: What if the theory doesn't account for defeaters effectively?
8813e364-2106-4815-91bf-c756cc40c9d8.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person has a justified true belief without a false lemma, but new evidence appears (a defeater) suggesting the belief might be false. Intuitively, we would judge that the new evidence impacts whether the person truly has knowledge. No False Lemmas Theory may not adequately address the role of such defeaters.}

1393eaf8-9727-440e-87de-e1572369f7ee.summary: Does the theory adequately handle practical knowledge?
1393eaf8-9727-440e-87de-e1572369f7ee.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowing how to do something requires more than knowing propositions about it. This principle together with the No False Lemmas Theory entails that practical knowledge should conform to the same standards as propositional knowledge, including no false lemmas. It seems implausible when practical efficacy does not always align with theoretical justification.}

e7cfeaf9-79d3-4566-8d7f-12d4bcf27bb8.summary: Can knowledge be refuted by the presence of genuine but ignored evidence?
e7cfeaf9-79d3-4566-8d7f-12d4bcf27bb8.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person has all the evidence needed to believe truly, but they arbitrarily dismiss some of it, leading to conclusions based on selective justification. Intuitively, we either have to say that they know the proposition or that they do not. If we say they know it, then ignoring genuine evidence seems inconsequential. If we say they do not, then a flaw not related to false lemas undermines knowledge.}

166919d5-ce10-4ba2-8154-1a2c96c17c73.summary: Can someone know a proposition if there's no direct causal link between the belief and the truth?
166919d5-ce10-4ba2-8154-1a2c96c17c73.content: {Imagine a case where a person believes that it will rain tomorrow because they saw clouds in the morning. The proposition that it will rain tomorrow is true because of an unrelated storm system formed later. Intuitively, we might think the person does not truly know it will rain tomorrow.}, {The causal connection between the belief and truth required for knowledge is missing despite the belief's truth and correctness being based on the true future occurrence.}

aa618f9e-2aa8-4344-9d64-63d3eb0981aa.summary: Can coincidental beliefs qualify as genuine knowledge under the theory?
aa618f9e-2aa8-4344-9d64-63d3eb0981aa.content: {Suppose a person believes they will win the lottery due to a lucky charm. Unexpectedly, they win, and their belief turns out true. Intuitively, we would say that having such a belief based on a lucky charm does not amount to knowledge.}, {The lottery outcome is true, and the person believes it, but the causal connection between belief and truth lacks epistemic grounding, challenging the sufficiency of truth, belief, and causal connection for knowledge.}

986dd611-5d2d-472e-9858-c4bd1465ff5f.summary: Does knowledge require an understanding of the causal connection?
986dd611-5d2d-472e-9858-c4bd1465ff5f.content: {Consider a person who believes someone else is in the next room because they hear a noise. Unknown to them, the noise was artificial, but the person actually was in the next room for different reasons. Intuitively, it does not seem appropriate to say the person knows the other person is there.}, {Even though there's a belief, truth, and coincidental presence, the lack of awareness of the causal mechanism makes the knowledge claim problematic.}

83621b28-29e6-4e96-9af2-9220e6603877.summary: How do cases of deviant causal chains impact the causal theory of knowledge?
83621b28-29e6-4e96-9af2-9220e6603877.content: {Suppose a detective believes a suspect is guilty because of evidence that turns out to be faked by the suspect, but the suspect is indeed guilty for other reasons. Intuitively, we may not consider this as the detective genuinely knowing the suspect's guilt.}, {The existence of a causal link is insufficient if the link is deviant or not epistemically appropriate, indicating a limitation of the causal theory's conditions for knowledge sufficiency.}

e1fd67a3-5c86-44ef-bdd1-f86bd3f9512b.summary: Can one have knowledge if they reach the truth through faulty reasoning?
e1fd67a3-5c86-44ef-bdd1-f86bd3f9512b.content: {Suppose a student believes their answer in an exam is correct due to incorrect reasoning, but coincidentally the answer matches the correct solution. Intuitively, it seems incorrect to suggest the student knows the answer just because they reached the truth.}, {The belief and truth coincide, but the absence of an appropriate causal chain from belief to truth undermines the claim of knowledge.}

240144a2-8147-4497-8690-65b80e97b808.summary: Does the causal theory account for knowledge in cases of reliable processes?
240144a2-8147-4497-8690-65b80e97b808.content: {Imagine someone uses a well-calibrated thermometer to determine the outside temperature, forming a belief about the temperature that is true. Intuitively, this seems to constitute knowledge.}, {The knowledge seems to depend on the reliability of the process, rather than a specific causal interaction between belief and specific truth, raising concerns about the necessity of a direct causal link.}

f043437f-8907-4e9f-826f-90ad731c80b8.summary: How does perceptual knowledge fit into the causal theory framework?
f043437f-8907-4e9f-826f-90ad731c80b8.content: {Consider a person who sees a tree and thus believes a tree is in front of them. Intuitively, this perceptual belief seems like knowledge.}, {While there is a causal link from the tree to visual perception to belief, distinguishing these cases from other possible perceptual illusions raises complexities about appropriate causal connections.}

c7a2d5f8-c93d-47dc-8bc2-c9ab16884328.summary: What happens in cases of pre-established harmony?
c7a2d5f8-c93d-47dc-8bc2-c9ab16884328.content: {Suppose two events occur independently yet yield a coincidental belief where a person thinks their alarm will go off at 7 AM, and it does due to a power reset. Intuitively, we hesitate to claim this is knowledge.}, {The causal theory struggles to account for the lack of a causative link between the reason for belief and the proposition's truth, showing insufficiency in the account's sufficiency condition.}

1895227f-a44b-40d5-8995-701704c6fab5.summary: Does the causal theory handle testimonial knowledge adequately?
1895227f-a44b-40d5-8995-701704c6fab5.content: {Imagine a scenario where a person believes a historical fact because they read it in a reputable history book. Intuitively, we treat this belief as knowledge.}, {The causal connection between belief and truth is mediated by testimony, raising issues about the causal requirement's ability to accommodate indirect links.}

de96e7a6-adfc-4f35-809d-52207270fa52.summary: Can knowledge claims remain justified when based on false foundational reasons?
de96e7a6-adfc-4f35-809d-52207270fa52.content: {Consider a philosophy student who, due to a typing error, believes Aristotle was Plato's student. It’s true, but the student had a wrong reason related to a different philosopher's biography. Intuitively, we might refuse to accord the student knowledge.}, {Even though the student holds a true belief, the faulty reason undermines robust causal connection, threatening the causal theory’s claim on knowledge sufficiency.}

a02f27e5-0ba5-4b51-b932-1ab42f6f6150.summary: Can intellectual virtues ensure knowledge in the presence of environmental luck?
a02f27e5-0ba5-4b51-b932-1ab42f6f6150.content: {A person can form a true belief through intellectual virtue about a proposition while being in a situation where external circumstances could have easily led to a false belief.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person notices a barn on a road known for having many fake barns nearby. The person believes it is a real barn because it is in fact a real barn, and their belief happens to be true and formed through an intellectual virtue such as careful observation. Nevertheless, it is plausible to intuitively judge that the person does not know it's a real barn because the presence of fake barns undermines the reliability of the belief despite intellectual virtue.}

3d74b0b8-94ea-4533-8fd5-f0668e6448e5.summary: Can a belief formed through intellectual virtue actually fail to result in knowledge due to internal defects?
3d74b0b8-94ea-4533-8fd5-f0668e6448e5.content: {Consider a person who forms a true belief through intellectual virtue but simultaneously holds internally irrational beliefs that would undermine their justification if they were to reflect on those beliefs.}, {A person named Alex forms a belief that a bridge is safe through carefully analyzing blueprints, which is an exercise of intellectual virtue. However, Alex also irrationally believes without evidence that troll magic keeps bridges safe. Despite forming the correct belief about the bridge's safety through virtue, holding an irrational belief about the troll magic undermines the intuition that Alex's belief counts as knowledge.}

c1c9c531-8c0b-4322-8100-81fe9e77de9d.summary: Do Gettier cases pose a challenge to virtue epistemology?
c1c9c531-8c0b-4322-8100-81fe9e77de9d.content: {A typical Gettier scenario involves a person forming a true belief through justification, but due to luck rather than virtue, leading to intuitive judgments against counting as knowledge.}, {Suppose Jamie sees a broken clock showing noon and, based on observing the clock, believes it is noon when it coincidentally is noon. Although Jamie's belief is accidentally true and formed by looking at the clock, it is formed through a method compromised by the clock’s dysfunction, showing that luck, not virtue, is responsible for the belief being true.}

3536420f-8800-40e8-9b69-28e5a5b49442.summary: Can the dependency on the concept of 'intellectual virtue' be too vague or potentially circular?
3536420f-8800-40e8-9b69-28e5a5b49442.content: {The notion of 'intellectual virtue' encompasses traits such as open-mindedness and intellectual courage, but lacks precise criteria for determining which traits contribute to knowledge.}, {Suppose there is a need to distinguish when curiosity as an intellectual virtue results in knowledge versus when it leads to over-imaginative conjecture that results in error. Without explicit criteria, appeals to intellectual virtues are circular if they rely on specifying virtues by their success in producing knowledge.}

bd4999f5-c03b-4d95-a929-aefb94f58e01.summary: Does cognitive integration strictly lead to knowledge through virtue?
bd4999f5-c03b-4d95-a929-aefb94f58e01.content: {Cognitive integration refers to a seamless, reliable use of intellectual faculties, like reasoning and memory, suggesting virtues are integrated rather than compartmentalized skills.}, {Consider a scenario in which a person reliably forms true beliefs using both reasoning and memory. If their intellectual virtues such as perception and deduction are at odds, showing bias or uncritical adoption of false conclusions from others, then despite cognitive integration, the person fails to know certain propositions.}

c4114130-d6d7-45dd-b6ee-51d8969bd571.summary: Can a person with intellectual virtues fail to know due to lack of success in application?
c4114130-d6d7-45dd-b6ee-51d8969bd571.content: {Intellectual virtues require successful application to attain knowledge, involving a correct strategy and circumstance.}, {Consider Terry, an accomplished chess player who usually predicts opponents' moves accurately through strategic thinking, an intellectual virtue. If Terry predicts a move correctly during an uncharacteristically lucky situation that wasn't based on their strategic analysis, the virtue doesn't suffice to claim Terry knows the move beforehand.}

71e2033f-d7e1-45de-9ee8-454a0ade05ed.summary: Could a belief formed purely from luck yet through apparent virtue undermine knowledge?
71e2033f-d7e1-45de-9ee8-454a0ade05ed.content: {Suppose a student, Emma, forms a belief about a scientific fact by sheer coincidence overhearing an expert conversation matching her own premature conclusion. Her belief accidentally aligns with expert knowledge, appearing to be virtue-formed due to timing and verification.}, {The intuition arises that Emma doesn't know the scientific fact since her belief's accuracy stems from luck rather than a genuine intellectual exercise, pointing out that virtue incidental to such luck evades true knowledge formation.}

1c78dd88-c01e-41b5-acc8-7a3e365de6be.summary: How does the accessibility of intellectual virtue support raise issues of epistemic access?
1c78dd88-c01e-41b5-acc8-7a3e365de6be.content: {Epistemic access implies awareness or accessibility to the reason one's belief is true, separating it from knowledge derived subconsciously, relying on virtue-based deliberations.}, {Consider a magician who instinctively performs a trick involving probability and deductive skills, an assumed application of intellectual virtues. If asked, the magician cannot explain why the trick succeeds probabilistically, suggesting a lack of epistemic access, thus challenging their knowledge claim.}

984ee64c-3bcc-43e7-ba19-39d21e447a23.summary: Does practical use of intellectual virtues necessarily translate into propositional knowledge?
984ee64c-3bcc-43e7-ba19-39d21e447a23.content: {Intellectual virtues apply to diverse practical activities beyond forming true belief, such as art or sport, yet these activities may enrich understanding without contributing propositional knowledge.}, {An artist might display intellectual courage in breaking conventions, enhancing aesthetic value while not directly contributing to knowledge of art history. This raises questions about whether such virtues suffice for knowledge strictly by propositional standards.}

851cc6bb-896a-45b0-89bd-867970b2cb97.summary: Can socially embedded beliefs hinder knowledge despite intellectual virtues?
851cc6bb-896a-45b0-89bd-867970b2cb97.content: {Socially embedded beliefs maintain influence over individual minds, challenging whether virtue alone assures independent true belief formation, essential to knowing.}, {Suppose someone adopts health behaviors based on societal norms in exercising intellectual humility by following expert consensus. While using virtues intellectually upheld, such external unilateral acceptance could miss deeper personal critical evaluation, thus compromising autonomous knowledge.}

cf27597c-bd92-438f-a199-b1d350eacecc.summary: Does Contextualism lead to inconsistency across different contexts?
cf27597c-bd92-438f-a199-b1d350eacecc.content: {Consider a scenario where a person knows a proposition in one context but fails to know the same proposition in another context because of different standards. Inconsistently, the proposition is both known and not known.}, {There is a plausible principle that if a proposition is known at all, it should be consistently known regardless of changing contexts. This principle together with varying context standards implies inconsistency.}

b9d09bce-8b76-4b73-baef-578245d91482.summary: Can contextualism undermine the concept of knowledge itself by making it too variable?
b9d09bce-8b76-4b73-baef-578245d91482.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should have a stable definition to guide understanding and assessment. This principle conflicts with contextual standards that allow for constant variation in the definition of knowledge.}, {If contextualism is correct, a person could claim to 'know' the same proposition at different times with varying evidential standards, making 'knowledge' an unreliable concept.}

2b2258f3-86c6-4306-b16e-459dc609518b.summary: Does contextualism lead to confusion in everyday knowledge claims?
2b2258f3-86c6-4306-b16e-459dc609518b.content: {Suppose in one context a person is justified in claiming knowledge of a fact with minimal evidence, whereas in another context stronger evidence is required. This creates confusion about what counts as knowledge.}, {It is implausible that the same proposition can oscillate between being knowledge and not knowledge based purely on contextual changes, because everyday language relies on clear knowledge claims.}

230d7780-88c0-4bd2-8783-8dbef64105f4.summary: Is contextualism too permissive in allowing subjective standards for knowledge?
230d7780-88c0-4bd2-8783-8dbef64105f4.content: {Consider a scenario where an individual's context allows weak standards for knowledge, leading to claims of knowledge without strong evidence. This scenario permits subjective bias in knowledge claims.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge requires objective evidence regardless of context; contextualism permitting otherwise could result in subjective distortion.}

68c508e0-4fc4-4b5f-baae-9dda2f099d08.summary: Does contextualism fail to account for disagreement between knowledge claims?
68c508e0-4fc4-4b5f-baae-9dda2f099d08.content: {Suppose two people from different contexts disagree on whether a proposition is known based on their differing standards of justification. There is no common ground for resolving this disagreement.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge claims should be reconcilable to facilitate understanding, but varying contexts obstruct this resolution.}

5e3c0349-4a09-4bea-94d3-d65fe1b41f5b.summary: Does contextualism undermine intersubjective verification of knowledge?
5e3c0349-4a09-4bea-94d3-d65fe1b41f5b.content: {Consider a scenario where person A knows a proposition under their contextual standards, while person B does not recognize this as knowledge due to their own context. This makes shared verification problematic.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should be verifiable by others for shared understanding, but contextualism weakens this verification criterion.}

07cf3e73-48bb-4d37-9a35-ede949a7a855.summary: Does contextualism make it difficult to critique or improve belief systems?
07cf3e73-48bb-4d37-9a35-ede949a7a855.content: {It is implausible that beliefs justified within one context cannot be critiqued by another context with different standards, as this blocks critical evaluation and progress.}, {If standards shift with context, then identifying flawed beliefs becomes difficult because they are 'justified' differently across contexts.}

3da6b21a-1179-4cde-becb-9021ac9e5884.summary: Does contextualism imply that moral knowledge is relative to context?
3da6b21a-1179-4cde-becb-9021ac9e5884.content: {Consider if moral knowledge claims are accepted or rejected based on contextual standards, leading to moral relativism where moral truths shift with context.}, {There is a plausible principle that moral knowledge, if it exists, should not be entirely context-relative, because this destabilizes the foundation of moral inquiry.}

c3b0ccaa-99ff-45f2-b052-0303cd924e77.summary: Can contextualism result in the exclusion of minority knowledge claims?
c3b0ccaa-99ff-45f2-b052-0303cd924e77.content: {Suppose a minority group operates under different contextual standards for knowledge. Their claims might be excluded by the dominant context's standards.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge claims should be inclusively evaluated to prevent marginalization, which contextualism's shifting standards might fail to ensure.}

acabe0f9-80a0-4483-9317-85876fd8a18d.summary: Does contextualism create an issue with historical knowledge claims?
acabe0f9-80a0-4483-9317-85876fd8a18d.content: {Suppose historical claims were justified under different past contexts yet considered not known under present contexts. This creates a tension in preserving historical knowledge.}, {It is implausible that historical knowledge should lose its status based on changing contemporary standards, as this disrupts the continuity of knowledge over time.}

90d0e11e-5bbf-4b12-b41d-e9e7bfc987d5.summary: Can contextualism generate paradoxes of knowing when contexts overlap?
90d0e11e-5bbf-4b12-b41d-e9e7bfc987d5.content: {Consider a scenario where overlapping contexts provide conflicting standards for knowing the same proposition, resulting in paradoxes such as mutually exclusive knowledge states.}, {There is a plausible principle that overlapping contexts should allow for coherent transitions between standards, but contextualism's flexibility can lead to paradoxes.}

1a0c4b16-58c7-4708-8e15-b1bdad8bf04e.content: {A person can believe a proposition, the proposition can be true, and believing it can lead to a successful action, yet intuitively we would not attribute knowledge to the person because success could be due to luck or coincidence.}, {A case where someone flips a coin and believes it will land heads, it in fact lands heads, and they win a bet due to the belief resulting in a practical benefit, does not seem to involve knowledge despite belief, truth, and practical benefit.}

0c1c90f0-11f1-48cb-a082-90261434923d.summary: Can false beliefs provide practical success?
0c1c90f0-11f1-48cb-a082-90261434923d.content: {There are instances where false beliefs can lead to successful action or practical benefit, yet these instances intuitively do not constitute knowledge.}, {A person who believes falsely that the bridge is safe when it is not, yet successfully crosses due to an coincidental structural support, does not possess knowledge even if the belief led to a successful outcome.}

5e0070f9-dae1-4b36-a3a4-743729fdc1fc.summary: Is practical utility a marker of knowledge?
5e0070f9-dae1-4b36-a3a4-743729fdc1fc.content: {It is implausible that practical utility, or benefit derived from a belief, is a necessary condition for knowledge in all cases.}, {A mathematician can know a theorem to be true even if believing it never results in any practical benefit but is grounded solely in proof and truth.}

dc05ba27-ec46-4aae-80c6-a811ba69f9bc.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person believes something for a reason unrelated to the actual truth of the matter, though the belief coincidentally leads to a practical benefit.}, {In such a case, intuitively, we would not say that the person knows the proposition because their belief's truth and practical success are accidental and not grounded in epistemic justification.}

d86d0e3f-1d94-4a74-a2e2-fc245f989b16.summary: Does pragmatic benefit reduce knowledge to luck?
d86d0e3f-1d94-4a74-a2e2-fc245f989b16.content: {A plausible principle is that knowledge should not rely on luck, yet if pragmatic benefit can arise purely due to chance, then knowledge under this view can result from luck.}, {Scenarios in which an individual successfully benefits from a belief due to fortuitous, unforeseen factors do not align with our intuitive understanding of knowledge.}

a5efc266-e0b3-4062-8666-26639347dee1.content: {It is implausible that knowledge cannot exist without practical application or successful action resulting from the belief.}, {Knowing historical facts or complex theoretical knowledge without immediate practical application is intuitively seen as genuine knowledge despite lacking direct pragmatic benefits.}

ee6a1b7b-9cba-44a7-95a5-082927af8b20.summary: Can beliefs yield opposite practical outcomes?
ee6a1b7b-9cba-44a7-95a5-082927af8b20.content: {Believing a true proposition may lead to different practical outcomes depending on context, thus challenging knowledge being tied to practical success.}, {A person believing a proposition may engage in an action that is successful in one context but unsuccessful in another, yet intuitively, their knowledge does not fluctuate based on context.}

b060453b-ca21-4326-aaaa-1afa20ffe7b1.summary: Is epistemic justification necessary for knowledge?
b060453b-ca21-4326-aaaa-1afa20ffe7b1.content: {A case where someone has a justified belief in a true proposition, yet due to unforeseen factors, it results in no practical benefit, is still intuitively seen as knowledge.}, {Epistemic justification appears necessary for knowledge, suggesting pragmatic success is not sufficient on its own if justification is absent.}

faecb3b4-f9ee-4aa0-9f9d-4c007b8d74c8.summary: Can belief alone be a sufficient condition for knowledge?
faecb3b4-f9ee-4aa0-9f9d-4c007b8d74c8.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person believes a proposition based solely on a guess, and the proposition happens to be true. Intuitively, it seems incorrect to say that the person knows the proposition, even if they believe it and it is true.}

51680daa-268d-401f-b005-0264b12ff4ed.summary: Can intellectual intuition reliably lead to true knowledge?
51680daa-268d-401f-b005-0264b12ff4ed.content: {There is a plausible principle that intellectual intuitions are not always reliable indicators of truth. This principle together with the requirement for knowledge being derived from intellectual intuition suggests that not all cases labeled as knowledge actually are.}

970e11c1-9540-4592-8cb0-57605053ec36.summary: Is intellectual intuition distinguishable from other psychological processes?
970e11c1-9540-4592-8cb0-57605053ec36.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person's belief is influenced by unconscious biases or desires. Intuitively, it becomes difficult to separate intellectual intuition from such other processes, casting doubt on the claim that knowledge is derived purely from intellectual intuition.}

df3ec3d0-2d93-4e06-b6fc-9d0974b72e8d.summary: How can we verify the truth of propositions known through intuition?
df3ec3d0-2d93-4e06-b6fc-9d0974b72e8d.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge requires verifiable evidence. Propositions known solely through intellectual intuition may lack verifiable evidence, suggesting such knowledge might be unjustifiably claimed.}

d1435317-6072-4189-ae56-b481b437862b.summary: Can false propositions be intuitively known?
d1435317-6072-4189-ae56-b481b437862b.content: {Consider a scenario where a person strongly intuits a false proposition to be true. Intuitively, this undermines the reliance on intellectual intuition as a method for acquiring true knowledge, as it can lead to falsehoods.}

637693ba-b252-424b-a329-db73d7ff595b.summary: Is intuitively generated belief a reliable source of truth?
637693ba-b252-424b-a329-db73d7ff595b.content: {It is implausible that beliefs generated by intellectual intuition always lead to truth without external validation, raising doubts about the necessity and sufficiency of intuition for knowledge.}

d53081f0-1336-47d0-81c0-367ceab9b9c1.summary: Can intellectual intuition provide immediate justification?
d53081f0-1336-47d0-81c0-367ceab9b9c1.content: {There is a plausible principle that justification for knowledge typically requires an evidential basis. Intellectual intuition lacks an evidential basis, challenging the view that it can provide immediate justification for knowing a proposition.}

d1076587-f813-477d-866d-69cc78765ccf.summary: Could shared intuitions reflect cultural biases rather than truth?
d1076587-f813-477d-866d-69cc78765ccf.content: {Consider a scenario where intellectual intuitions held by a group reflect culturally specific biases. Intuitively, these shared intuitions do not necessarily align with objective truth, thus challenging the reliability of intuition as a source of true knowledge.}

b0c12949-f1ea-49f2-bf5f-67ca91e2bec9.summary: Is the necessity of belief in knowledge undermined by cases of knowing without believing?
b0c12949-f1ea-49f2-bf5f-67ca91e2bec9.content: {Consider a scenario where someone instinctively acts in accordance with a true proposition without consciously believing it. Intuitively, this suggests they might know the proposition despite lacking explicit belief, challenging the necessity of belief in knowledge.}

03a414e4-9646-463d-b0ca-dd3bfe9e42c1.summary: Does the sufficiency condition ignore the complexity of knowledge acquisition?
03a414e4-9646-463d-b0ca-dd3bfe9e42c1.content: {It is implausible that belief, truth, and intuition alone can account for all instances of knowledge. This view omits factors such as context, evidence, and justification, suggesting the insufficiency of the specified conditions for knowledge.}

a6a76f26-d427-4998-9d2c-70fb0a6e7d6a.summary: Are intuitive beliefs sensitive to counter-evidence?
a6a76f26-d427-4998-9d2c-70fb0a6e7d6a.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person's belief, generated by intellectual intuition, remains unchanged despite contradictory evidence. Intuitively, the insensitivity to evidence questions the reliability and sufficiency of intuition-based beliefs in constituting knowledge.}

4a0c09c1-10ce-411d-be74-0440751f3554.summary: Does the requirement for truth discount valuable false knowledge?
4a0c09c1-10ce-411d-be74-0440751f3554.content: {Consider a scenario where believing a false proposition leads to beneficial results or pragmatic success. Intuitively, this scenario suggests that some forms of false knowledge can still hold value, challenging the strict requirement for truth in knowledge.}

c6f38ecd-6dba-41de-90c2-5724d855207b.summary: Does intellectual intuition account for the variety of knowledge domains?
c6f38ecd-6dba-41de-90c2-5724d855207b.content: {There is a plausible principle that different domains of knowledge, such as empirical science and mathematics, rely on differing foundations. Intellectual intuition may not be equally applicable across all domains, challenging its necessity and sufficiency in every context.}

826722ef-ebe9-45a0-8234-de9f5873d9d2.summary: Are immediate intuitions influenced by emotional states?
826722ef-ebe9-45a0-8234-de9f5873d9d2.content: {It is plausible that emotional states can influence what individuals intuit, calling into question whether intuitions are stable or reliable sources of truth necessary for knowledge.}

a0c6ef10-9ee9-41e9-9958-949ffabd3974.summary: Can intuition-based knowledge be communicatively shared with others?
a0c6ef10-9ee9-41e9-9958-949ffabd3974.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should be communicable to others. Intellectual intuitions may lack the communicative clarity and structure to be effectively shared, challenging their role as a basis for knowledge.}

bed2d9e9-50bf-426a-b610-6c4ec8f02359.summary: Can potential defeaters always be fully anticipated?
bed2d9e9-50bf-426a-b610-6c4ec8f02359.content: {A defeater is something that undermines or rebuts the justification for the belief in question.}, {Suppose there could be defeaters that are not currently identifiable or recognizable because of limitations in the individual's perspective or conceptual framework.}, {If there are defeaters that might emerge in a future context or perspective that is inaccessible to the individual, then the sufficiency condition of the theory is threatened because one cannot ensure justification is free from undefeated defeaters.}

e4f3c1b4-709a-4c69-8598-3628984927c4.summary: Is the condition of undefeated defeaters too demanding?
e4f3c1b4-709a-4c69-8598-3628984927c4.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual has overwhelming evidence and justification for a belief, yet there exists a highly unlikely but possible counter-evidence that is unknown to them.}, {It is implausible to demand that for knowledge all possible defeaters must be known and defeated, as it sets an unrealistic standard for human epistemic agents.}, {If the condition requires that all potential defeaters—seen or unforeseen—must be defeated or considered, then it makes knowledge practically unattainable in many cases.}

de3fcf20-4192-4f7b-b1a6-ae97925c7750.summary: Is the connection between defeaters and justification clear enough?
de3fcf20-4192-4f7b-b1a6-ae97925c7750.content: {A defeater is supposed to affect justification for a belief, yet not all cases of a seemingly justified belief failing conjunctively satisfy the truth and belief conditions involve identifiable defeaters.}, {There could be scenarios where an individual's belief is justified and true, yet intuitively it does not constitute knowledge due to factors like luck or coincidence, which do not represent clear defeaters.}, {If luck or other non-defeater-based conditions can invalidate knowledge claims, then the theory's reliance on defeaters may be inadequate in defining knowledge.}

26b39cf0-d95a-42b4-aec2-0a0bb6b89623.summary: Is the exclusion of emotional or social factors as defeaters problematic?
26b39cf0-d95a-42b4-aec2-0a0bb6b89623.content: {Consider a situation where a person's otherwise justified claim is influenced by strong emotions or social pressures, leading them to unknowingly overlook relevant evidence.}, {In such a case, it might be argued that emotional or social factors act as defeaters, though traditionally they may not be considered such.}, {If emotional or social factors can undermine justification without being recognized as traditional defeaters, the theory might overlook important aspects that affect knowledge.}

eb74d538-bae3-4894-b4cb-8bd8e68d0e44.summary: Does the theory adequately address Gettier cases?
eb74d538-bae3-4894-b4cb-8bd8e68d0e44.content: {Gettier cases are scenarios where individuals have justified true belief without knowledge due to the involvement of some form of epistemic luck.}, {A standard example would involve a person who forms a belief through justified reasoning, but unknown to them, an unseen factor makes their belief true by chance.}, {If Gettier cases represent genuine instances where the knowledge condition is not met despite having no apparent undefeated defeaters, the theory might be inadequate if it fails to rule out these cases.}

da52e42d-bacb-43ce-8ea7-2abaec0bfcb1.summary: How does the theory handle environmental epistemic luck?
da52e42d-bacb-43ce-8ea7-2abaec0bfcb1.content: {Environmental epistemic luck occurs when a belief is justified and true, but the environment or context makes this true in a way that seems accidental or fortuitous.}, {For instance, someone may guess the result of a coin flip correctly based on reliable but irrelevant evidence, with no apparent defeaters present.}, {If such cases do not constitute knowledge yet cannot be explained by the theory through the presence of defeaters, this indicates an explanatory gap.}

daa89a24-ef49-49a7-ae9f-5a1d575faf3a.summary: Can the theory distinguish between propositional and doxastic justification?
daa89a24-ef49-49a7-ae9f-5a1d575faf3a.content: {Propositional justification refers to having sufficient reason for a proposition, while doxastic justification involves properly forming the belief based on that proposition.}, {Consider a case where a person has propositional justification for a claim due to evidence but forms the belief based on an irrelevant reason like superstition, without knowing of any defeaters.}, {If the theory cannot distinguish when beliefs are improperly formed despite propositional justification without involving defeaters, insufficiency in explaining what constitutes knowledge might arise.}

228bdb55-0daa-4b52-9965-6d62b58da175.summary: Is the notion of undefeated defeaters too context-relative?
228bdb55-0daa-4b52-9965-6d62b58da175.content: {The presence or absence of an undefeated defeater can depend heavily on the context and available evidence, which varies significantly between different situations.}, {Suppose two individuals have identical justified true beliefs, but one is aware of a potential defeater while the other is not due to differing contexts or access to information.}, {If the point at which a defeater counts as defeated is too context-relative, the theory may lack the objectivity needed to consistently define knowledge.}

14e548bc-20d0-41cc-8584-0886d8442038.summary: Can memory errors serve as defeaters even when not recognized?
14e548bc-20d0-41cc-8584-0886d8442038.content: {Consider a scenario where an individual has a true belief that is justified by evidence, but their memory of that evidence is faulty, unbeknownst to them.}, {This could lead to a situation where justification is undermined by memory error as a defeater, causing the belief to lack knowledge status.}, {If memory errors can serve as defeaters without the knower's recognition, the theory might not account adequately for how knowledge can be defeated unknowingly.}

39926222-f987-40a8-ab0c-e4df09a96d85.summary: Are there cases where all conditions are met yet intuitively not knowledge?
39926222-f987-40a8-ab0c-e4df09a96d85.content: {Suppose a young child believes correctly that it is raining outside based on seeing others with wet umbrellas, satisfies belief, truth, and lacks known defeaters.}, {The child's belief formation process is non-inferential and largely accidental, lacking understanding or appropriate evidence processing.}, {If such beliefs, meeting all conditions, intuitively do not constitute knowledge, questions arise regarding the theory's sufficiency in capturing the essence of knowledge.}

7a596e4d-d4b1-4070-9c90-f9cc2a3431e5.summary: Doesn't the demand for infinite reasons create an impossible standard for knowledge?
7a596e4d-d4b1-4070-9c90-f9cc2a3431e5.content: {It is impractical for humans to have an infinite chain of reasons for any belief, given limited cognitive resources}, {In real-world scenarios, individuals often successfully claim to know things without explicitly enumerating or possessing an endless chain of reasons}, {Requiring an infinite series of reasons for justification seems to contravene common understandings of knowledge, which often involve finite and manageable sets of justifications}

672fc365-c9af-49ee-a03a-af6f709fba4e.summary: How do you deal with cases of forgotten but adequate justification?
672fc365-c9af-49ee-a03a-af6f709fba4e.content: {Sometimes a person can have knowledge of a proposition even if they can no longer remember the reasons that originally justified that belief}, {In cases where someone once had adequate reasons but has now forgotten them, they can still be said to have knowledge intuitively}, {This implies that an endless chain of present reasons may not be necessary for justification, which challenges the necessity of infinite reasons}

264e58f6-9eb6-47be-a2bd-56ddcb6b9f37.summary: Isn't this circularity problem an issue for infinite regression?
264e58f6-9eb6-47be-a2bd-56ddcb6b9f37.content: {In any system of reasons, if each reason requires another reason, there is a risk of circular justification where reasons eventually loop back to the original}, {Infinitism might inadvertently allow for circular justifications to emerge, which are traditionally considered problematic and undermine the claim to genuine knowledge}, {If some steps in the chain of reasons are allowed to circle back, this could invalidate the claim of providing genuine justification by infinite regress}

73f762d5-6947-492e-a104-42a3d464b9c8.summary: Could finite beings ever actually achieve an endless chain of reasons?
